content:
Downvoted :(

Overall, clashes that ask for input validation of different return type, plus performing a simple operation is just pure artificially bad, point blank ... Also,

* Following is wrong, because 32.0 is also a number, same goes for 3.1428... 

> if the input is not a number print INVALID

Instead it should be

> if the input is not an integer print INVALID

* Missing cases for -000 && 000 since you've mentioned this

  > - Strings starting with '0' are considered valid, example : '012' => 0

edited the "-" in a middle case
added a separate one for that

Hello,
The "non-digit" validator is problematic.
There is no example visible by coders showing "12-5" is invalid, nor explicit rule telling it's invalid.
As Waffle3z said TWO YEARS AGO, the validator should not test an hidden case.

The one-digit case doesn't make sense. The sum of all of the digits except for the first one is zero, and multiplying the first digit by zero is zero. It's written as a note that this should be special-cased to just return the input, but the only case where this applies is hidden in a validator, which is bad. This just shouldn't be part of the problem.
This contribution hasnâ€™t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE", "SHORTEST" options has therefore been deactivated.

several quirky testcases are only in the validators
- one digit but negative
- non-digit but ok as part of a number (-/+) in the middle

this shouldn't have been approved
Edited for more understandable test cases

Contribution updated ;)
Thanks guys for your remarks :)
Explain and add a case when there is juste one digit

"and multipl the summing's result with the first digit"
The English verb is "multiply", "summing's result" should be changed to "sum", and there should be "." at the end of each sentence.

"if S is not an integer print INVALID"
Then 012 is invalid, as there are no leading zeros in any number, not just integers.

"Given a string S which contains digits"
Test and Validator 4 don't  satisfy this condition at all.

There is nothing about negative numbers in the description. "Integer" and "number" are mixed in the description.

Title also misses a "y" at the end of multiply, and "It" somehow starts with capital "I".

After correcting these, it could be accepted, although as Stilgart mentioned it is quite easy when not played in reverse mode.
", and multipl the summing's result with the first digit" would probably easier to read as: ", and then multiplying the result with the first digit"
Yet another 10s clash of code.

There is no precision about negative numbers. It seems that you consider the "first digit" as negative if the whole number is negative.
Maybe it's a good, but quite difficult, challenge to solve it without explanation or with the shortest code.
It seems "Input" and "Output" sections are not populated in usual format...

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

hello
what did u mean by populated in usual format ?

"Be careful, the first digit may be negative (starting with '-') !"
There are no negative digits, only negative numbers.

My problem with the proposal that you are talking about numbers when giving examples, and there are test cases (the INVALID ones), where the input is not a number. For a clash, where most people just read the problem as fast as they can and not very thoroughly, it can be a problem.

Also, I'm still positive that this problem is impossible in reverse mode.

If there are no confusion in the statement, and reverse mode is removed, I will accept it.

The test cases ('INVALID' ones) are made to make the clash a lite bit difficult, and in reverse mode i think it will be clear; when the user will see 15Ml66=>INVALID i think he will undertand "if S,the input, is not an integer the output will be "INVALID" ;)

The relevant input-output pairs for reverse mode that are not invalid
123 -> 5
0 -> 0
-593 -> -60
-1 -> -1
I have a degree in theoretical mathematics, almost got my PhD, but I will never, ever find out what should I do, based on two test cases checks the trivial one digit, return itself rule.
It means you have two test cases to generalize. A world famous professor of mine told me once that only great mathematicians can generalize from two cases (and the most brilliant ones can do it from one case).
I mean in the way described in the examples.

are the tests not clear ? if so which one ? 
ways to improve this ?
Thanks
No no, all clear, I just did a marginal style remark.
